JOEBIALEK

This is the second part to an earlier writing about education in the United States. As you may recall, I advocated for the privatization of all schools from kindergarten to graduate studies. This piece will focus on the curriculum that needs to be followed. 
 
 Everytime I encounter someone in the workplace, I am reminded of just how much we have failed to properly educate United States citizens in the fundamentals of communication: reading, writing and speaking. Few would argue that the time is long overdue for the United States to "get back to the basics" of a fully functional education system. We need to exclusively focus on the development of communication skills from kindergarten to eighth grade along with annual testing that measures apptitude and interest. Training in mathematics should be limited to addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. Unless communication skills are fully mastered, there is no need to advance to high school. 
 
 For those who graduate to high school, the emphasis could evolve into a curriculum of philosophy, sociology, economics, psychology, science and religious studies. Books such as "For Dummies" and "The Complete Idiot's Guide" could be used to foster an understanding of different religions. Athletic activity would be strictly confined to cardio vascular exercises and all sports would be eliminated. While there would still be an emphasis on communication skills, the focus would now be on developing a foundation of basic knowledge so as to be able to graduate to college. Testing for apptitude and interest would continue through high school increasing the chances of picking the right field of study . Those not continuing on to college would enter some type of apprenticeship training for the purpose of learning a trade. For those who do graduate to college, the student would continue to study an advanced version of the same curriculum as high school but only for the first two years then they would complete their education by strictly focusing on coursework designed to train them in their field of study. Nearing graduation, internships would be required to begin the transition to the working world. Think of how different our society would be if our education system could just teach the fundamentals of reading, writing and speaking.
Bassman

There is an inherent problem with this, though. First off, what about visual and performing arts? Second is accessibility. Although I'm quite displeased with the liberal agenda that is force-fed through our children today, privatizing schools would put the nation's poorest at a disadvantage.
Clive14

Second is accessibility. Although I'm quite displeased with the liberal agenda that is force-fed through our children today, privatizing schools would put the nation's poorest at a disadvantage.
State funded education for all is a socialist concept. How can you call yourself a proper fascist if you support tax payer's money being used to pay for the education of those that cannot afford it?
Clive14

...Think of how different our society would be if our education system could just teach the fundamentals of reading, writing and speaking.
It ain't a pretty sight: a society devoid of music, theatre, science and technology. A society where no one would know what a globe was; what the names of the planets and star constellations were. A society devoid of knowledge and full of primitive superstitions.
georged

It ain't a pretty sight: a society devoid of music, theatre, science and technology. A society where no one would know what a globe was; what the names of the planets and star constellations were. A society devoid of knowledge and full of primitive superstitions.

 
 In the US, those primitive superstitions are alive and well.
Bassman

State funded education for all is a socialist concept. How can you call yourself a proper fascist if you support tax payer's money being used to pay for the education of those that cannot afford it?

 I support responsible usage of my tax dollars. I don't like the money being wasted on failing public schools where the only thing that teachers care about is their tenure. In Buffalo, the concept of Charter schools is taking off very well. I also support school vouchers.
Clive14

I don't like the money being wasted on failing public schools where the only thing that teachers care about is their tenure.
Do these schools fail in your view because the teachers only care about is their tenure, or do you only object to teachers caring about their tenure when they work at a failing school?
 
 
In Buffalo, the concept of Charter schools is taking off very well. I also support school vouchers.
That's nice for you. What are charter schools and school vouchers?
Bassman

Do these schools fail in your view because the teachers only care about is their tenure, or do you only object to teachers caring about their tenure when they work at a failing school?
These schools fail because The teachers only care about their tenure.
 
 
That's nice for you. What are charter schools and school vouchers?

 Good question. First, charter schools are public schools that are not bound by the school district, union rules, and all of the other hassles. Academic and discipline standards are generally higher, and the resulting test scores run circles around the "traditional" public schools. School vouchers are where the tax money that would have gone to the school goes directly to the parents of the pupils so that they could enroll their children into whatever school (private, parochial, etc.) they choose. The idea here is that the average American should not be bound by the notion that their children must go to the cesspool known as the public school system.
georged

These schools fail because The teachers only care about their tenure.
 
 
 Good question. First, charter schools are public schools that are not bound by the school district, union rules, and all of the other hassles. Academic and discipline standards are generally higher, and the resulting test scores run circles around the "traditional" public schools. School vouchers are where the tax money that would have gone to the school goes directly to the parents of the pupils so that they could enroll their children into whatever school (private, parochial, etc.) they choose. The idea here is that the average American should not be bound by the notion that their children must go to the cesspool known as the public school system.

 
 So that my tax money would be used for a parochial school controlled by belief system dogma? Let the churches fund their own forms of education without using public money. If parents want a child to attend a parochial school, it should be the responsibility of the parent, not the public. 
 
 Most members of society are what comprise the 'cesspool' of all public facilities. If they feel their children deserve a different form of education than what's offered with public funds, why don't they step up and pay for it?
Jo Bennett

I suspect paying teachers a decent wage would go a long way to improving things. You want enthusiastic, intelligent people to become teachers, you need them to fell valued. The likes of Bassman dicking on them to score political points only makes matters worse. Standards of education in the UK have improved significantly since teachers began to be paid a decent wage, it's no longer the incapable and those pursuing a vocation that go into teaching, there is a good career there.
JPSartre12

This is the second part to an earlier writing about education in the United States. As you may recall, I advocated for the privatization of all schools from kindergarten to graduate studies. This piece will focus on the curriculum that needs to be followed. 

 I am a firm believer in privatization of schools as well. Uncle Sam has done a dismal job by maintaining an educational monopoly, run by unionized labor unaccountable to the ultimate "customers". 
 
 
 Everytime I encounter someone in the workplace, I am reminded of just how much we have failed to properly educate United States citizens in the fundamentals of communication: reading, writing and speaking. Few would argue that the time is long overdue for the United States to "get back to the basics" of a fully functional education system. We need to exclusively focus on the development of communication skills from kindergarten to eighth grade along with annual testing that measures apptitude and interest. Training in mathematics should be limited to addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. Unless communication skills are fully mastered, there is no need to advance to high school.

 I totally disagree with that approach. Americans aren't getting their arses handed to them in communication, they're getting their brains beat out in mathematical-based sciences. China and Japan graduate 500,000 engineers/year; the US graduates 50-60k/year. Why? Because the mathematics involved in engineering curriculum is beyond the capabilities of most US HS graduates. It's much easier for them to go into fields that don't require a heavy background in math, precisely because of thinking such as yours above. 
 
 
 For those who graduate to high school, the emphasis could evolve into a curriculum of philosophy, sociology, economics, psychology, science and religious studies. Books such as "For Dummies" and "The Complete Idiot's Guide" could be used to foster an understanding of different religions. 

 And doing so would put US students even further behind their global competitors. The world runs on science, why handicap our kids further?
 

 Athletic activity would be strictly confined to cardio vascular exercises and all sports would be eliminated. 

 Great, OBE sports. No winners, just "participation trophies". That really teaches kids how to compete in a competitive global marketplace. emoticon_rolleyes 
 

 While there would still be an emphasis on communication skills, the focus would now be on developing a foundation of basic knowledge so as to be able to graduate to college. Testing for apptitude and interest would continue through high school increasing the chances of picking the right field of study . Those not continuing on to college would enter some type of apprenticeship training for the purpose of learning a trade. For those who do graduate to college, the student would continue to study an advanced version of the same curriculum as high school but only for the first two years then they would complete their education by strictly focusing on coursework designed to train them in their field of study. Nearing graduation, internships would be required to begin the transition to the working world. Think of how different our society would be if our education system could just teach the fundamentals of reading, writing and speaking.

 
 Ah yes, the "worker bee" theory of education. Identify the worker bee early enough and you don't have to waste time educating him on such inane topics such as math and science. Just increase theyr dexterity to the point at which they can turn a wrench adroitly. No thanks. That's the way communist states think, not free ones.
 The fact is that, in today's world EVERYONE needs a college-level education. I live in the automotive capital of the world and as high priced manual labor jobs leave, the displaced workers aren't qualified to do anything that requires a brain. Is that the future that you want? Or do you think that these "worker bees" will be satisfied making Third World worker bee wages for the rest of their life?
 Ever wonder how a country devoid of natural resources, like Japan, can become a world economic power? They do it because their greatest natural resource is brain power. What is it that is bringing up India and several former USSR states economies? Brain power. Kiev, for example, is becoming a magnet for foreign investors wanting to do basic chemical research. India is a magnet for computer programming. 
 
 The problem isn't that Americans can't communicate. The problem is that nobody is hiring bullshooters. They want workers with technical knowledge to help them solve real problems, such as how to generate more energy economically, how to move masses of people more efficiently, etc., The world isn't lining up at the doors of American orators, I can guarantee you that.
Bassman

So that my tax money would be used for a parochial school controlled by belief system dogma? Let the churches fund their own forms of education without using public money. If parents want a child to attend a parochial school, it should be the responsibility of the parent, not the public. 
 
 Most members of society are what comprise the 'cesspool' of all public facilities. If they feel their children deserve a different form of education than what's offered with public funds, why don't they step up and pay for it?

 Ahh yes! Right in lock-step with the NEA? Look the public schools have had their little monopoly long enough. Why not let the poor be able to choose the school they waht for their children? And why not let them have the funds that would be allocated for the school system?
georged

Ahh yes! Right in lock-step with the NEA? Look the public schools have had their little monopoly long enough. Why not let the poor be able to choose the school they waht for their children? And why not let them have the funds that would be allocated for the school system?

 
 Think for a moment about why many people are poor and then rephrase the question.
JPSartre12

So that my tax money would be used for a parochial school controlled by belief system dogma? Let the churches fund their own forms of education without using public money. If parents want a child to attend a parochial school, it should be the responsibility of the parent, not the public. 
 
 Most members of society are what comprise the 'cesspool' of all public facilities. If they feel their children deserve a different form of education than what's offered with public funds, why don't they step up and pay for it?

 
 Why not give everybody a choice? Since we're so deeply rooted in a socialist education system, why not allocate $X per student and let parents decide where to spend it? And if a parochial school's tuition is 1/2 of the public school's but you get 2X the education, is that a problem for you? emoticon_wow
georged

Why not give everybody a choice? Since we're so deeply rooted in a socialist education system, why not allocate $X per student and let parents decide where to spend it? And if a parochial school's tuition is 1/2 of the public school's but you get 2X the education, is that a problem for you? emoticon_wow

 
 I pay taxes for specific purposes managed by civil servants. If the masses are unhappy with that situation, they, IMO, have two choices:
 
 1. Pay for alternative methods of education they deem necessary.
 
 2. Change that civil service management by using their voting privileges. 
 
 As the general public has proven itself apathetic to reality and easily manipulated by anyone who can muster a platform to promise them everything from ever lasting life to personal safety, why would I be so stupid as to trust their personal judgment in spending my money?
daewoo

Ah yes, the "worker bee" theory of education. Identify the worker bee early enough and you don't have to waste time educating him on such inane topics such as math and science. Just increase theyr dexterity to the point at which they can turn a wrench adroitly. No thanks. That's the way communist states think, not free ones.
 The fact is that, in today's world EVERYONE needs a college-level education. I live in the automotive capital of the world and as high priced manual labor jobs leave, the displaced workers aren't qualified to do anything that requires a brain. Is that the future that you want? Or do you think that these "worker bees" will be satisfied making Third World worker bee wages for the rest of their life?
 Ever wonder how a country devoid of natural resources, like Japan, can become a world economic power? They do it because their greatest natural resource is brain power. What is it that is bringing up India and several former USSR states economies? Brain power. Kiev, for example, is becoming a magnet for foreign investors wanting to do basic chemical research. India is a magnet for computer programming. 

 
 Japan became a world economic power because they had a good mix of thinkers and doers. We have the thinkers int he US, we lack those willing to do. This is why we have assembly line workers making $35 an hour, plumbers making more than doctors, and auto mechanics pulling down $100K per year. Skilled or semi skilled workers are hard to come by. business majors or even engineers are a dime a dozen. We cannot keep the ones we DO have employed. 
 
 Our colleges have become an extension of high school. We are turning out more people with college degrees, sure, but the quality of their education is pathetic. Yet they get out of college and expect better than an assembly line job, so they join the ranks of middle management. Many companies who move their production offshore do so not only to save labor costs, but becuase there is an abundance of skiled workers available and they get better product. 
 
 The absolute LAST thing we need is more colledge educated middle management drones running around. If nothing else, the layoffs we have sen in the last year should have taught us that you can remove a significant portion of your middle management and it makes your company more effective, not less. Lets face it, the middle management retards have built the buracracy int his country to the point that the cost of supporting it makes the price production labor look insignificant. THAT is where we need to start cutting. Cuts in production labor inevitably lead to local corrections in the labor market. People are out of work for a few months, which drives down labor prices, which creates jobs as companies take advantage of the lower labor rates to expand.
 
 Youar average blue collar worker that is unemplyed draws unemployment for 4 months and is then back in the workforce. Your average white collar worker who is unemplyed maxes out their unemployment, making it nearly impossible to accuratly gauge how long they remain unemployed (though most estimates put it at 9 month to a year).
 
 We need more indians, less chiefs.
JPSartre12

I pay taxes for specific purposes managed by civil servants. If the masses are unhappy with that situation, they, IMO, have two choices:
 
 1. Pay for alternative methods of education they deem necessary.
 
 2. Change that civil service management by using their voting privileges. 
 
 As the general public has proven itself apathetic to reality and easily manipulated by anyone who can muster a platform to promise them everything from ever lasting life to personal safety, why would I be so stupid as to trust their personal judgment in spending my money?

 
 Since we are stuck with a governmentally-funded educational system that would take an act of God to change in the short-term, why not let market forces work as much as possible? Schools that produce will have higher enrollment and those that don't will go belly up. Surely as a devout capitalist you see the benefits of that. 
 Or are you saying that the masses can't be trusted to make good choices so "Big Government" must make them for us? That would be a very anti-capitalist approach, don't you think? emoticon_rolleyes
Bassman
It seems that George and his liberal friends are afraid of losing control of academia. Just like they lost control of the media and the Government. And just like they're losing control of the courts.
JPSartre12

It seems that George and his liberal friends are afraid of losing control of academia. Just like they lost control of the media and the Government. And just like they're losing control of the courts.

 
 Georged isn't a liberal, IIRC. That's why his position is so surprising to me. I'm an old Jeffersonian Liberal, but depart from Jefferson's philosophy on public education. I don't see it as a government's responsibility. But since that battle has been fought and lost, the least we could do is make education competitive and not just hand it over to the NEA and other special interest groups that don't have education as their top priority.
 I've fought the battles against my local NEA and I know the death grip that they have on education here in Michigan. I want to see competition so that **** poor schools with **** poor teachers lose their funding and jobs. emoticon_mad
Symbiote

The problem with school vouchers is that while they may make public schools more competitive, they give the government a far greater degree of control over private schools, since the government decides whether they are worthy of being the recipients of public money or not.
JPSartre12

The problem with school vouchers is that while they may make public schools more competitive, they give the government a far greater degree of control over private schools, since the government decides whether they are worthy of being the recipients of public money or not.

 
 I think that's part of the reform that needs to take place. If we decouple payment from control, the system would work much better.
Bassman
The NEA has such a stranglehold on public education it's not funny. They even dictate the curricula of the teachers. How's that for size?
Symbiote

I mean, do you really think that school vouches will be allowed to be used by anything calling itself a "school" that has dedicated pupils? Let's say I want to send my kids to the "Evilotion is rong sk0ol of christian prayers", or the "America sux school of holocaust denial" - either it's open to absolutely anything or some standards have to be set, and ultimately the ruling party will manipulate those standards until public and private schooling is indiscernable.
 
 In the long run, the combined voucher system may prove even less competitive, since there is no independant private school stream public schools have to face off against.
Bassman
One of my previous posts defined what a Charter School is. In fact, that's the other alternative that I like because they aren't beholden to the NEA.
JPSartre12

I mean, do you really think that school vouches will be allowed to be used by anything calling itself a "school" that has dedicated pupils? Let's say I want to send my kids to the "Evilotion is rong sk0ol of christian prayers", or the "America sux school of holocaust denial" - either it's open to absolutely anything or some standards have to be set, and ultimately the ruling party will manipulate those standards until public and private schooling is indiscernable.

 You bring up a good point. There has to be some "standard" set on some level. In the past, those standards have been set locally. Federal influence on education is a relatively recent phenomenon and started with Jimmy Carter creating the Department of Education as a payback to teacher unions for getting him elected. 
 

 In the long run, the combined voucher system may prove even less competitive, since there is no independant private school stream public schools have to face off against.

 
 Private schools can still be free to not accept Federal funding and, therefore, the strings that come attached. We have two colleges in the US that are reknown for NOT taking any gov't money. Not surprisingly, at least one, Hillsdale, is very conservative. It's late and the other school's name escapes me at the moment.
georged

Since we are stuck with a governmentally-funded educational system that would take an act of God to change in the short-term, why not let market forces work as much as possible? Schools that produce will have higher enrollment and those that don't will go belly up. Surely as a devout capitalist you see the benefits of that. 
 Or are you saying that the masses can't be trusted to make good choices so "Big Government" must make them for us? That would be a very anti-capitalist approach, don't you think? emoticon_rolleyes

 
 I think the rot is too deep for short-term solutions. The public willingly conceded academic curriculum control to the federal government by allowing accreditation at all levels to be placed under political control for purposes of equality, creating widespread mediocrity. 
 
 The quality of US higher education has been effectively crippled by combining financial aid for students with school accreditation dictated by federally mandated curriculum, further diluting academic quality. As Daewoo accurately points out, we're churning out college grads effectively educated to a point of high school mediocrity with inapplicable skills.
 
 To expand that mediocrity by granting public funding to any entity thrown together that meets federal academic requirements will further dilute quality of education and greatly increase federal control of curriculum. While you obviously favor parochial schools, and they have done a fine job in the past, it would create an explosion of schools for profit with dubious academic intent. 
 
 Those who champion a voucher program might as well be honest and state they desire fascist state schools. That would create absolute federal control over everything from dress codes to curriculum meeting the lowest possible academic standard to facilitate each and every student.
 
 This is a constitutional republic. The general public has expressed apathy for quality education and encouraged fiscal irresponsibility by enabling and supporting leadership with all the qualities of banana belt dictators. Until that public proves itself capable of demanding and structuring positive change within the system it creates, I don't care to trust their obviously flawed, personal judgment on how to better spend my tax money.
JPSartre12

I think the rot is too deep for short-term solutions. The public willingly conceded academic curriculum control to the federal government by allowing accreditation at all levels to be placed under political control for purposes of equality, creating widespread mediocrity. 

 You may be right, but supporting the status quo as you would seem to be in favor of, amounts to throwing one's hands up and crying "Uncle". 
 

 The quality of US higher education has been effectively crippled by combining financial aid for students with school accreditation dictated by federally mandated curriculum, further diluting academic quality. As Daewoo accurately points out, we're churning out college grads effectively educated to a point of high school mediocrity with inapplicable skills.

 I think that you're painting with too broad a brush. I have three kids in college as I write this and I can tell you that the one going to engineering school is about 3 years ahead of where I was when I got my bachelor's degree in chemistry in 1978. He surpassed my mathematic ability (which included 4 semesters of Calculus in college) by the end of his senior year in HS. Granted, he attended a gifted high school, but I've seen his college level mathematics courses and they're light-years ahead thanks to computers and the like.
 

 To expand that mediocrity by granting public funding to any entity thrown together that meets federal academic requirements will further dilute quality of education and greatly increase federal control of curriculum. While you obviously favor parochial schools, and they have done a fine job in the past, it would create an explosion of schools for profit with dubious academic intent. 

 I'm surprised with that answer. What you are describing " To expand that mediocrity by granting public funding to any entity thrown together that meets federal academic requirements will further dilute quality of education and greatly increase federal control of curriculum" fits our current governmentally-controlled educational monopoly to a tee. Isn't it about time that we changed our paradigm on education?
 

 Those who champion a voucher program might as well be honest and state they desire fascist state schools. That would create absolute federal control over everything from dress codes to curriculum meeting the lowest possible academic standard to facilitate each and every student.

 How so? IMO, it would give flexibility to parents to send their kids to schools that meet their needs and desires. If the parents wanted a strict environment, that could be one option. If the parents wanted a more open school, they could choose that as well. How does absolute freedom promote fascism? Unles you're saying that the majority of Americans would become fascist by choice. emoticon_confused
 

 This is a constitutional republic. The general public has expressed apathy for quality education and encouraged fiscal irresponsibility by enabling and supporting leadership with all the qualities of banana belt dictators. Until that public proves itself capable of demanding and structuring positive change within the system it creates, I don't care to trust their obviously flawed, personal judgment on how to better spend my tax money.

 
 So, IYO, the public must first try to repair the irrepairable BEFORE they can do something different? And the only reason that there is a belief that the public is apathetic is because most have bought into the teacher union dogma that the way to cure a crappy educational system is to throw more money at it (and right into teachers' pockets). My days of being intimately involved in public education are waning. Three years from now, I probably won't have a single kid in any educational institutional institution anywhere. But, I stil want to see change because without change, we're getting our heads handed to us in the world arena of manufacturing and other science-based endeavors.
georged

So, IYO, the public must first try to repair the irrepairable BEFORE they can do something different? And the only reason that there is a belief that the public is apathetic is because most have bought into the teacher union dogma that the way to cure a crappy educational system is to throw more money at it (and right into teachers' pockets). My days of being intimately involved in public education are waning. Three years from now, I probably won't have a single kid in any educational institutional institution anywhere. But, I stil want to see change because without change, we're getting our heads handed to us in the world arena of manufacturing and other science-based endeavors.

 
 I don't consider the general public responsible enough to do anything but fill their bellies, reproduce and seek mindless entertainment. Our political direction has displayed that ignorance by our elected representatives, leadership, catering to general public desires for purposes of securing elected office. Your opinions are seemingly based on your own experiences and from your posts other than those regarding blind patriotism, I would not consider you a member of the general public. Our economic heads were handed to us in the 1970s when our standard of living created few requirements to be competitive, including education. We're now paying the price for that conceit.
JPSartre12

I don't consider the general public responsible enough to do anything but fill their bellies, reproduce and seek mindless entertainment. Our political direction has displayed that ignorance by our elected representatives, leadership, catering to general public desires for purposes of securing elected office. Your opinions are seemingly based on your own experiences and from your posts other than those regarding blind patriotism, I would not consider you a member of the general public. Our economic heads were handed to us in the 1970s when our standard of living created few requirements to be competitive, including education. We're now paying the price for that conceit.

 
 And how much of that conceit do you attribute to a public educatiuon system that rates #1 in the world in generating self-esteem in students but way back in the pack on math, science, etc., where it REALLY matters?
 The mindlessness of most Americans is precisely because they are products of a mindless educational system, one that you want to continue, status quo. 
 As for my "blind patriotism", if you mean that I support my country and don't try to undermine its efforts, then I'm guilty as charged and proud of it.
 If by that you think that I automatically rubberstamp everything that our government does, then you're way off base. If it was up to me, we'd have a part-time legislature with little power outside of protecting borders and regulating interstate commerce and an infinitely smaller budget to spend.
georged

And how much of that conceit do you attribute to a public educatiuon system that rates #1 in the world in generating self-esteem in students but way back in the pack on math, science, etc., where it REALLY matters?
 The mindlessness of most Americans is precisely because they are products of a mindless educational system, one that you want to continue, status quo. 
 

 
 The public generally gets what it wants. That's what politicians pander to for purposes of election. When enough of the general public finally realizes the easy way is not normally the best way, and they aren't there yet, they'll change. It may take living in cardboard boxes or such for a few years, but they'll eventually understand the strength of any nation is its youth and their education. Only the public, with responsible leadership, has the power to make that change.
 
 Tilting at windmills is not my idea of spending time in a productive manner.
JPSartre12

The public generally gets what it wants. That's what politicians pander to for purposes of election. When enough of the general public finally realizes the easy way is not normally the best way, and they aren't there yet, they'll change. It may take living in cardboard boxes or such for a few years, but they'll eventually understand the strength of any nation is its youth and their education. Only the public, with responsible leadership, has the power to make that change.
 
 Tilting at windmills is not my idea of spending time in a productive manner.

 
 Well, pardom me if I think that the time to change course is BEFORE we drive off the cliff.
georged

Well, pardom me if I think that the time to change course is BEFORE we drive off the cliff.

 
 The word 'we' sounds like you're personally in the doomed vehicle headed for the cliff. Hopefully you've planned ahead and have the ability to change rides. The alternative is convincing a majority of the 90% of voters who still have the pedal to the metal to put on brakes and and reduce your crash results to major injuries. Prying them away from their boob tubes, credit card interest only payments along with fast food meal diets and enlightening them to the fact that they're in for a crash will be a truly admirable achievement.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Education Part ll
